newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: ALPINE SKIING-FRITZ STROBL WINS DEMANDING KITZBUEHEL DOWNHILL.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-FRITZ STROBL WINS DEMANDING KITZBUEHEL DOWNHILL.

text.p: In-form Austrian Fritz Strobl again edged out compatriot Werner Franz to clinch his second World Cup victory on Saturday, on the most demanding downhill slope on the men's circuit.
Last month Strobl stopped Franz claiming his first-ever victory at the season's opening downhill in Val D'Isere, by only two-hundredths of a second.
On Saturday, Strobl performed a breathtaking run on the dreaded 3,312-metre long Streif piste, for a winning time of one minute 51.58 seconds to beat Franz by 0.57 seconds.
Strobl slashed compatriot Guenther Mader's course record from last year of 1:54.29 by almost three seconds, even though the piste was flagged with more gates this winter and was longer.
Frenchman Luc Alphand, who won Friday's two-run sprint downhill on a shortened version of the course on the Hahnenkamm mountain, was third in 1:52.20.

A delighted Strobl said: "I didn't think I was doing that well during the run because I felt I was all over the place. But when I saw the number one on the scoreboard, I knew it wouldn't be such a bad day after all."
Strobl is the only Austrian to have won downhills this winter and has therefore virtually guaranteed himself a starting bib at the world championships in Sestriere, which begin on February 2.
He is also the only skier other than Alphand and Italian Kristian Ghedina to have won in the downhill this season.
